head.title: Congress Seeks to Reduce Greenhouse Effect

hedline.hl1: Congress Seeks to Reduce Greenhouse Effect

block.p: The Worldwatch Institute's ''State of the World, 1989'' study recommends that national energy policies be directed to reduce carbon emissions from fossil fuels, the principal cause of the greenhouse effect (news story, Feb. 12).

Such a policy is sought by a global-warming-prevention bill to be introduced in Congress by Representative Claudine Schneider and 56 others. The bill calls for a reduction in emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, and proposes ways to promote energy efficiency and use of renewable resources. It also calls for action on deforestation, the elimination of chlorofluorocarbons, the promotion of family planning services and other measures to deal with the environmental crisis.
Most important, the bill establishes a strategy for reducing greenhouse gases and energy costs at the same time. Specifically, it calls for:
* A 20 percent global reduction of 1987 carbon dioxide levels by 2005.
* Authorization of at least $868 million over three years for research and development into energy efficiency.
* New fuel consumption standards for vehicles of 45 miles a gallon for light cars and 35 miles a gallon for light trucks.
* $805 million over three years for research and development into solar and renewable resources.
* Establishment of an office of recycling research and information in the Department of Commerce to promote recycling programs.
The global-warming-prevention bill is a step toward counteracting the environmental calamity that is bearing down on us. JONATHAN HURDLE Brooklyn, Feb. 15, 1989
